episode_summary: This episode of "No Such Thing As A Fish" covers a range of intriguing topics, including the peculiar last words of Socrates, the surprising influence of BBC Radio 4 on UK heating systems, Andy Warhol's unique approach to wig maintenance, and the amusingly named village of Ugly, which played a role in the planning of Stansted Airport.

facts.fact: My fact this week is that when Socrates lost feeling in his penis, he asked his friend to sacrifice a cock.
My fact is that a lot of people in the UK have their heating controlled by BBC Radio 4.
My fact this week is that Andy Warhol would regularly have his wig cut by a barber and then return the following month wearing a new longer wig.
Okay, my fact this week is that when Stansted Airport was being planned, locals, complaining to maintain the area's natural beauty, often met in a village called Ugly.
